form.official-title: To reform and modernize domestic refugee resettlement programs, and for other purposes.

section.header: Domestic refugee resettlement reform and modernization

paragraph.text: The term community-based organization means a nonprofit organization providing a variety of social, health, educational and community services to a population that includes refugees resettled into the United States.
The term Director means the Director of the Office of Refugee Resettlement in the Department of Health and Human Services.

The term national resettlement agencies means voluntary agencies contracting with the Department of State to provide sponsorship and initial resettlement services to refugees entering the United States.

subsection.header: Assessment of refugee domestic resettlement programs

paragraph.text: As soon as practicable after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General of the United States shall conduct a study regarding the effectiveness of the domestic refugee resettlement programs operated by the Office of Refugee Resettlement.
In the study required under paragraph (1), the Comptroller General shall determine and analyze—

subparagraph.text: how the Office of Refugee Resettlement defines self-sufficiency and integration and if these definitions adequately represent refugees’ needs in the United States;
the effectiveness of Office of Refugee Resettlement programs in helping refugees to meet self-sufficiency and integration;
technological solutions for consistently tracking secondary migration, including opportunities for interagency data sharing;

the Office of Refugee Resettlement’s budgetary resources and project the amount of additional resources needed to fully address the unmet needs of refugees with regard to self-sufficiency and integration;
the role of community-based organizations in serving refugees in areas experiencing a high number of new refugee arrivals;
how community-based organizations can be better utilized and supported in the Federal domestic resettlement process;
recertification processes for high-skilled refugees, specifically considering how to decrease barriers for Special Immigrant Visa holders to use their skills; and
recommended statutory changes to improve the Office of Refugee Resettlement and the domestic refugee program in relation to the matters analyzed under subparagraphs (A) through (G).

paragraph.text: Not later than 2 years after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall submit to Congress the results of the study required under this subsection.

paragraph.header: Assistance made available to secondary migrants
paragraph.text: Section 412(a)(1) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1522(a)(1)) is amended by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: The Director shall ensure that assistance under this section is provided to refugees who are secondary migrants and meet all other eligibility requirements for such assistance.

paragraph.text: Section 412(a)(3) of such Act (8 U.S.C. 1522(a)(3)) is amended—

subparagraph.text: by inserting (A) after (3);
by striking periodic and inserting annual; and
by adding at the end the following:
At the end of each fiscal year, the Director shall submit a report to Congress that includes—

clause.text: States experiencing departures and arrivals due to secondary migration;
the impact of secondary migration on States hosting secondary migrants;
the availability of social services for secondary migrants in those States; and
unmet needs of those secondary migrants.

paragraph.text: Section 412(c)(1)(B) of such Act (8 U.S.C. 1522(c)(1)(B)) is amended—

subparagraph.text: by inserting a combination of— after based on;
by striking the total number and inserting the following:
by striking the period at the end and inserting the following:

clause.text: the total number of all other eligible populations served by the Office during the period described who are residing in the State as of the beginning of the fiscal year; and
projections on the number and nature of incoming refugees and other populations served by the Office during the subsequent fiscal year.

paragraph.text: Not later than 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act and not later than 30 days before the effective date set forth in paragraph (5), the Director shall—

subparagraph.text: issue a proposed rule for a new formula by which grants and contracts are to be allocated pursuant to the amendments made by paragraph (3); and
solicit public comment regarding such proposed rule.

paragraph.text: The amendments made by this subsection shall become effective on the first day of the first fiscal year that begins after the date of the enactment of this Act.
The Director shall expand the Office of Refugee Resettlement’s data analysis, collection, and sharing activities in accordance with the requirements set forth in paragraphs (2) through (5).

paragraph.header: Data on mental and physical medical cases

subparagraph.text: coordinate with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, national resettlement agencies, community-based organizations, and State refugee health programs to track national and State trends on refugees arriving with Class A medical conditions and other urgent medical needs;
examine the information sharing process, from country of arrival through refugee resettlement, to determine if access to additional mental health data could—

clause.text: enable agencies to better prepare to meet refugee mental health needs; and

subparagraph.text: in collecting information under this paragraph, utilize initial refugee health screening data, including—

clause.text: a history of severe trauma, torture, mental health symptoms, depression, anxiety, and posttraumatic stress disorder recorded during domestic and international health screenings; and
Refugee Medical Assistance utilization rate data.

paragraph.text: The Director shall partner with State refugee programs, community-based organizations, and national resettlement agencies to collect data relating to the housing needs of refugees, including—

subparagraph.text: the number of refugees who have become homeless; and
the number of refugees who are at severe risk of becoming homeless.

paragraph.header: Data on refugee employment and self-Sufficiency
paragraph.text: The Director shall gather longitudinal information relating to refugee self-sufficiency, integration, and employment status during the 2-year period beginning 1 year after the date on which the refugees arrived in the United States.

subparagraph.text: update the data collected under this subsection; and
submit a report to Congress that contains the updated data.

paragraph.text: The Secretary of State shall provide guidance to national resettlement agencies and State refugee coordinators on consultation with local stakeholders pertaining to refugee resettlement.

The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in collaboration with the Secretary of State, shall collect best practices related to the implementation of the guidance on stakeholder consultation on refugee resettlement from voluntary agencies and State refugee coordinators and disseminate such best practices to such agencies and coordinators.

subsection.text: This section (except for the amendments made by subsection (c)) shall take effect on the date that is 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act.
